Award.AwardTitle: RII Track-2 FEC: Low-Cost, Efficient Next-Generation Solar Cells for the Coming Clean Energy Revolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical description
This Research Infrastructure Improvement Track-2 Focused EPSCoR* Collaboration (RII Track-2 FEC) award to Brown University is for a collaboration with the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and Rhode Island College. The project focuses on the development of solar cells using compounds called perovskites (the name perovskite derives from their crystal structure). The project includes materials research to understand structural, electrical, and optical properties of perovskites, development of non-toxic perovskite materials for use in solar cells, experimentation to enhance power conversion efficiency, and exploration of scale-up processes for low-cost, high efficiency perovskite solar cells. The collaboration provides mentoring for junior faculty and the critical mass effort is expected to enhance research capacity, infrastructure, and train skilled workforce in both Rhode Island and Nebraska. The educational training for graduate student includes courses on entrepreneurship; undergraduates from 4-year colleges (including Tougaloo College in Mississippi) and high school teachers are engaged in summer research/camps. SciToons for YouTube will be developed in partnership with Rhode Island School of Design to increase the scientific awareness of solar cell research for clean energy production.

Technical description
The project addresses scientific and technological challenges in the development of hybrid perovskite solar cells (PSCs) including: (1) Understanding of solution-deposition mechanisms and effects on nano-/micro- structure of hybrid perovskites; (2) development of solution-processing methods and scale-up of processes for high throughput fabrication and potential commercialization of solar cells; (3) experimentation of electrode materials and solar cell efficiency enhancement through plasmonic concentrators and tandem devices; and (4) exploration of lead-free materials for use in low-cost, high-efficiency PSCs through computational and experimental validation. The work involves synthesis of hybrid perovskite materials in the form of thin films, bulk polycrystals, and single crystals; characterization using a variety of spectroscopic, microscopic and crystallographic methods; and studies of optical and transport properties and the interplay between ferroelectricity and photovoltaic response with an aim to improve the stability of PSCs. The project team will explore technologies such as roll-to-roll printing and doctor-blade coating for scalable manufacturing as well as carbon-based electrodes, plasmonic concentrators, and tandem devices to improve the power conversion efficiency of PSCs. The team will also pursue the discovery and studies of lead-free perovskite systems (methylammonium tin iodide, metal halide, potassium platinum chloride, and bismuth-based perovskites) to develop environmentally-safe materials for use in PSCs. The project involves ten faculty members, 16 graduate students, 17 undergraduate students and one high school teacher in research, as well as 12 teachers in summer camps on solar energy. The K-12, public outreach activities leverage ongoing programs and are focused on renewable/solar energy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This multi-institutional, multi-jurisdictional project performed comprehensive, integrated research — ‘PSCs: from molecules towards the marketplace’ —addressing the formidable science and technology challenges faced by the new perovskite solar cells (PSCs). The project was divided into four interrelated thrusts according to those challenges, and the thrusts integrated experiments and modeling (see graphic). Brown University and Rhode Island College (RIC) in Rhode Island (RI) jurisdiction and University of Nebraska Lincoln (UNL) in Nebraska (NE) jurisdiction participated in this project.

 

While PSCs are showing great promise, the basic structures and properties of the relevant organic-inorganic halide perovskites (OIHPs), and the scientific underpinnings of structure-properties relations, were still not fully understood. To that end, Thrust 1: Hybrid Perovskite Materials and Basic Understanding addressed those issues holding back PSCs progress. The ability to deposit OIHP thin films in high-efficiency PSCs using low-cost solution processing is a huge advantage over conventional solar cells that require expensive equipment and high-temperature processes. However, the basic understanding of the solution-deposition mechanisms and their influence on the nano-/micro-structure of hybrid perovskites, and ultimately the properties, was still incomplete. Also, exploration of new solution-processing methods and scale-up of the processes for high-throughput fabrication and potential commercialization was in its infancy. Thus, Thrust 2: Processing and Scalable Manufacturing addressed those issues, to pave the way for scalable manufacturing of PSCs. Thrust 3: Solar Cell Devices and Efficiency Enhancement was to provide devices and testing support to the other three Thrusts, through experimentation with innovative electrode materials, and exploration of power conversion efficiency (PCE) enhancement through plasmonic concentrators and tandem devices. Although the amount of Pb in PSCs is very small and that issue could be mitigated through effective recycling programs, there has been a push towards eliminating Pb from PSCs in the long term. Thus, Thrust 4: Environmentally-Safe Materials Discovery explored new Pb-free materials for use in low-cost, high-efficiency PSCs through focused computations and experimental validation.

 

Broadly we have achieved sustainable critical-mass effort in photovoltaics (PVs) in RI and NE, which has been made possible by the enhanced research capacity/infrastructure, recruitment of new talent, and influx of research funding. The workforce development impacted K-12 through general public, where complementary strengths in RI and NE jurisdictions were leveraged. Specifically, activities at UNL included participation in the Nebraska Young Scientist summer program (K-12 students), the Nebraska Engineering Research program (underrepresented undergraduates), and Research Experiences for Teachers program. Activities in RI included: hosting underrepresented and/or non-traditional undergraduate researchers from RIC (a Primarily Undergraduate Institution or PUI) and Tugaloo College (an Historically Black Colleges or Universities, or HBCU) at Brown University during summers; developed one on-line course targeting community college students in future 'green' jobs; engaging Brown graduate students in entrepreneurship through the Technology Entrepreneurship and Commercialization program; held three public lectures on clean energy science and policy; developed three 'SciToons' animated films for YouTube on clean energy issues with a team of undergraduates; and trained several graduate students and postdocs in PVs research and education. Several junior faculty members who participated in this project were mentored by their senior faculty counterparts by leveraging existing activities at Brown and UNL.

 

This project has been highly productive, with 94 high-quality papers published in respected peer-reviewed journals, along with and 2 U.S. patents granted and 3 U.S. patents pending. Of the 99 total, 25 are individual, 58 are collaborative within an institution, and 16 are interjurisdictional between Brown University and UNL faculty investigators. A total of 45 posters and 13 conference talks were presented by the trainees, and the faculty investigators presented a total of 93 talks.

 

This NSF project was leveraged significantly in submitting several proposals to NSF and other federal agencies, of which 11 proposals have been awarded, totaling $3,476,087. Significant physical and intellectual infrastructure for PVs research was also built at Brown University and UNL.

 

Twelve faculty investigators from three institutions (Brown University, UNL, and RIC) participated in this project, six out of which were junior faculty members at some stage during the project. Other participants and trainees include: three K-12 school teachers, twenty-seven undergraduate student researchers, fifteen Ph.D. graduate students, and eleven postdoctoral researchers.
